awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites: Type I - University of Maine I-Corps Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, at the University of Maine, establishes an Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Site at this institution.

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

With an I-Corps Sites designation at the University of Maine, its Foster Center builds upon the programming and the university's research and development activities to support campus-based teams. The Site's innovation training supports the commercialization of natural resource-based technologies that can have a significant impact on rural communities. Maine relies on a natural resource-based economy and the state adopts unique tactics to remain innovative. 

The UMaine I-Corps Site program fills a critical gap between awareness and training and more intensive support programs. Involving teams in the I-Corps Site at an early stage in the commercialization pathway increases the likelihood of success as these teams move into more intensive accelerator and incubation programs and the next step in the commercialization pathway. The Site acts as a "pre-accelerator" helping them understand the market opportunities for their technologies through customer discovery and competitive and patentability analysis.

While supporting rural economic growth, the I-Corps Site also supports the full inclusion of women in entrepreneurship with a campus research center focused on recruiting, retaining, and advancing women faculty. Campus resources for women researchers are utilized and expanded with resources from I-Corps. The Foster Center incorporates training to help women entrepreneurs reach commercialization. The Foster Center has a strong history of promoting female entrepreneurship, and four out of five teams currently participating in the Center's Accelerator program are led by women. Notably, the I-Corps Site will be led by two successful and experienced female innovators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The University of Maine became a new I-Corps site and offered its first I-Corps cohort training in spring of 2019.  While our efforts were hampered in 2020 by the Covid-19 crisis, UMaine ultimately had 46 teams participate in the I-Corps Site over the life of this grant, exceeding the target of 41 teams. The participants are recruited through several programs at the Foster Center for Innovation at UMaine, such as the UMaine Research to Real World commercialization training for faculty, staff, and graduate students; faculty, staff, and students who seek help from the Foster Center for assistance with an idea; events and workshops; and outreach to the faculty, staff, and students who have received grants or who have submitted an invention disclosure. I-Corps participants are trained in customer discovery techniques and the Business Model Canvas.  Through their customer discovery activities, participants identify the 1-3 best high-potential market applications for product-market fit, value proposition, and growth opportunity.

Upon completion of I-Corps, teams are encouraged to pursue follow-on programs such as our MIRTA accelerator, National I-Corps, and Top Gun startup accelerator.  The I-Corps Site program has helped UMaine achieve its goal of creating a pipeline for the MIRTA research accelerator program and National I-Corps Teams training.

MIRTA is designed to advance the commercial readiness of selected projects  in a short period of time. The accelerator is an intensive 16-week program that guides participants through customer discovery, market analysis, intellectual property analysis, and business model development that results in a commercialization plan with a strategy for bringing their research to market. Each team is also matched with a group of mentors who provide advice at key points of the accelerator. Possible outcomes include a new startup company, a license to an existing company, or the formation of an extended research collaboration. Through weekly learning cycles, teams determine how to position and develop their research for commercialization success.

Team Results
Since becoming an I-Corps Site, UMaine recruited for three MIRTA cohorts (2020, 2021, and 2022). All twelve teams that were selected to participate in this opportunity had completed I-Corps programming prior to MIRTA participation, which enabled the teams to make greater gains during MIRTA. As a result of participation in the I-Corps Site and MIRTA programs, eight startups have been created and teams have raised more than $2.5 million dollars in non-dilutive funding.  Five teams completed the National I-Corps program.

Impact
One of the goals of UMaine's I-Corps site has been to translate technologies that can have a direct impact on economically distressed rural regions of our state. About one-third of the Site's I-Corps teams have innovations that are directly tied to Maine's natural resource economy and are well positioned to have an impact on rural Maine's forest, ocean, and agricultural sectors.  For some of these projects, access to raw materials, for instance, forest biomass for cellulose nanofibers that can be transformed into medical devices, is critical to success.  UMaine continues to work with these teams and partners to develop the unique supply chain and resources for these projects.  

Another goal of UMaine's Site was to broaden participation of groups traditionally underrepresented in commercialization activities. We hosted events featuring women and BIPOC entrepreneurs and innovators and held workshops with the UMaine's Multicultural Student Center. In addition, to address financial barriers to participation, UMaine provided stipends to some team members. Almost half of the teams had female Entrepreneurial Leads.

Maine is fortunate to have several excellent, albeit mostly small, non-profit research institutions.  These institutions, along with small colleges and universities in Maine, have excellent research, but often not enough critical mass to have their own I-Corps or accelerator programs. After becoming an I-Corps site, UMaine extended its programming to four teams from other Maine research institutions, broadening the impact of the program throughout the state.

The University of Maine's I-Corps Site has had a significant impact on building the entrepreneurial culture at UMaine and on commercialization results. It has created a platform for expanded activities to support the translation of deep technologies through commercialization for the University of Maine System and our partner research institutions and companies. UMaine plans to increase its customer discovery training activities and collaborate with partners to support participating teams in creating economic impact in Maine and beyond.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2023
Modified by: Renee Kelly
